awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Developing an Eco-Genomic Framework for Biofilter Operation.
awd_abstract_narration:
Biofilters use naturally-occurring microorganisms to filter and remove pollutants in drinking water without the need for disinfectant chemicals. Adoption of biofiltration is hindered by concerns that undesirable microorganisms will be released into the drinking water. Overcoming this concern would help pave the way for wide-scale adoption of this technology. The goal of this project is to develop a novel framework to control the biofilter microbial community. Such control will allow management of biofilter performance. To achieve this goal, the research team will perform laboratory and pilot-scale experiments using state-of-the-art genomic techniques to enrich beneficial microorganisms. The project team includes experts in drinking water treatment, biofiltration, and microbial ecology. The academic and industrial collaboration will help speed the transition of research to full-scale industrial implementation. 

Biofilter operation is guided by chemical and microbiological endpoints, yet current biofilter control approaches lack the nuance necessary for managing microbial communities. Considering this lack of control, it is no surprise that there is little to no knowledge of how biofilter microbes contribute to biofilter performance. This knowledge gap coupled with concerns about the seeding of the water distribution system with biofilter microbes has been a major stumbling block for the wide-scale industrial adoption of this technology. To overcome this barrier, this project will develop the novel Eco-Genomic Framework (EGF) for controlling the biofilter microbial community. This project focusses on using the EGF to tailor the biofilter microbial community to enhance post-filtration disinfection efficacy while maintaining biofilter performance. Preliminary EGF research results suggest that microbial disinfection resistance is associated with nitrogen species availability and resultant genetic stress response in biofilter microorganisms. This project will experimentally test EGF predictions 1) to establish a relationship between nitrogen species availability and nitrogen stress response exerted by biofilter microbes, 2) quantitatively link nitrogen stress response and disinfection resistance, and 3) optimize nitrogen species availability in the biofilter to maximize disinfection efficacy while minimizing potential deleterious impacts. These objectives will be accomplished through laboratory- and pilot-scale experiments coupled with state-of-the-art molecular, bioinformatics, and statistical approaches. The outcomes of this project will serve as proof of concept for the utility of the novel EGF for biofilter operation led by academic and industrial researchers with a track record of productive collaboration, thus increasing the likelihood of successful EGF development and industrial deployment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biological filtration, also known as biofiltration, is a sustainable and chemical-free approach for drinking water treatment. This involves allowing naturally occurring microorganisms to grow on media, such as activated carbon, typically packed inside filtration systems and then utilizing these microorganisms to destroy soluble contaminants and purify water as it passes through the biofilter. Biofilters have demonstrated the ability to remove a wide variety of pollutants provided they are operated under the right conditions. Nonetheless, the widespread adoption of biofiltration systems has been affected by concerns about the potential growth of (deleterious) microbes within the filters and their subsequent release into water output from the filter (also known as filter effluent) which is usually disinfected. This project proposed to develop an approach to facilitate the growth of microbes on the biofilter in such a way that the microbes that shed into the filter effluent are easily disinfected. This proposed approach was based on preliminary data that suggested manipulating nitrogen availability may allow for the growth of microorganisms in the biofilter that are easier to disinfect from the filter effluent.


The project included experiments with laboratory-scale biofiltration systems that were packed with filter media from a full-scale biofiltration system. We tested the impact of low levels of nitrogen species availability on the microbial community in the biofilters and their subsequent seeding ability (i.e., the ability to shed into the filter effluent). Three parallel biofilters were supplied with simulated groundwater amended either with low levels of ammonia or nitrate or ammonia and nitrate combined such that all three biofilters were fed the same total nitrogen. The biofilters were operated for several months and monitored for water treatment performance, as well as the microbial community on the filter and in the effluent. We found that differences in nitrogen species availability did impact the microbial community composition on biofilters and their seeding ability. The ammonia-fed filters consistently shed higher concentrations of microorganisms in the filter effluent as compared to the nitrate-fed filters. Nonetheless, a closer look at the filter microbial community using 16S rRNA gene sequencing revealed important insights into the types of microorganisms that were being enriched or depleted due to ammonia or nitrate and how these microbes were impacting the effluent. Specifically, while ammonia-feeding resulted in greater microbial growth on the biofilter, it also selected microbial populations that were less likely to shed into the effluent. In contrast, nitrate-feeding did not increase microbial concentration on the biofilter, but it selected for microbial populations that were more likely to shed into the effluent. This suggests that nitrogen species availability does impact the extent to which microorganisms from biofilters are shed into the filter effluent and their microbial identities. This is an important finding for the drinking water field as it brings to light the importance of managing nitrogen species availability in biofiltration systems. We further investigated the fate of these microbial communities when subject to disinfection using chloramine. Interestingly, despite the change in the microbial community within the biofilter and in the effluent due to differential nitrogen species availability, we were unable to detect any significant impact on disinfection efficacy. This was primarily because the disinfection efficacy of the biofilter effluent microbial community varied significantly over the course of the biofilter operation period. Further, investigations revealed that variable disinfection efficacy could be attributed to specific traits of the microbial community such as evenness, but we were unable to find any significant association between community evenness and nitrogen supply. The overall findings of this project are that while nitrogen species availability impacts the biofilter microbial community, post-filtration disinfection is an effective barrier for reducing microbial concentrations in the filter effluent. 

This project also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate researchers, interfaced with collaborators in the water industry, and enhanced education modules in the environmental engineering curriculum. Specifically, this project directly contributed to the training of one M.S. student, two Ph.D. researchers, and four undergraduate researchers, the majority of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. Graduate students supported by this work presented their findings through oral and poster presentations at national research and educational conferences. All undergraduate and graduate researchers were trained on a range of chemical and microbial water quality analysis techniques, as well as bioreactor operation and maintenance; these skills will be highly impactful as they develop their own independent careers in the water industry. The outcomes of this research have been integrated into educational modules taught at both Northeastern University and Georgia Institute of Technology. Overall, this project deepens our understanding of the impact of nitrogen species availability on biofilter operation and performance.
